nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a widely-used e-commerce platform offering a powerful set of features and tools for managing online stores. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a widely-used e-commerce platform offering a powerful set of features and tools for managing online stores. These features include marketing automation, customer management, inventory management, and order tracking. 

A key feature that enhances the user experience is the magnifier widget, allowing customers to zoom in on product images for a closer and more detailed view. This feature is especially useful for products with intricate details or small print.Â 

Implementing the magnifier widget in Magento 2 is an easy process involving basic configuration and customization. This blog will guide you through the necessary steps for how to implement a magnifier widget in the Magento 2 store. We will provide tips and best practices for optimizing the widget to ensure a seamless and engaging user experience for your customers, from selecting the right widget extension to installation and configuration on your site.

Steps to Implement Magnifier Widget in Magento 2

Step 1: Create a New Theme

The first step in implementing a magnifier widget is to create a new theme. This can be done in the following steps:

1. Log in to your Magento 2 admin panel.

2. Go to Content > Design > Configuration.

3. Select the store view for which you want to create a new theme.

4. Click on the “Create Theme” button.

5. Enter a name for your new theme and click on the “Save” button.

Step 2: Create a New Module

The next step is to create a new module. This can be done in the following steps:

1. Log in to your server using SSH.

2. Navigate to your Magento 2 installation directory.

3. Run the following command to create a new module:

lua

php bin/magento module:create --module-name=Namespace_ModuleName --vendor=Namespace --area=frontend

    Replace “Namespace_ModuleName” and “Namespace” with your desired module name and vendor name.

Step 3: Implement the Magnifier Widget

The final step is to implement the magnifier widget. This can be done in the following steps:

 1. Create a new template file for your product view page. This can be done by creating a new file in the following directory:

bash

app/design/frontend/Namespace/Theme/Magento_Catalog/templates/product/view/gallery.phtml

2. Copy the contents of the default Magento 2 gallery.phtml file into your new template file.

3. Add the following code to your new template file to implement the magnifier widget:

php

<div data-role="magnifier" data-magnifier-enabled="1" data-magnifier-params='{"width": "400", "height": "400"}'>

    <img class="gallery-placeholder"

         src="<?php /* @escapeNotVerified */ echo $block->getImageBlock()->getImageUrl(); ?>"

         data-src="<?php /* @escapeNotVerified */ echo $block->getImageBlock()->getImageUrl(); ?>"

         alt="<?php /* @escapeNotVerified */ echo $block->escapeHtml($block->getProduct()->getName()) ?>">

</div>

This code creates a container for the magnifier widget, sets the width and height of the magnified image, and specifies the image source.

4. Save your new template file and clear the Magento 2 cache by running the following command:

python

php bin/magento cache:clean

Testing the Magnifier Widget:

Before deploying the magnifier widget in your live store, it’s important to test it thoroughly to ensure that it works properly on different devices and browsers. You can use a testing tool such as BrowserStack or Sauce Labs to test the magnifier widget on various devices and operating systems. You can also test the widget on your own devices and ask your friends or colleagues to test it as well.

Customizing the Magnifier Widget:

You can customize the appearance and behavior of the magnifier widget by modifying the magnifier widget parameters. The available parameters include width, height, zoom level, animation speed, and more. You can also modify the CSS of the magnifier widget to change its appearance, such as the border color, background color, and position.

Using a Third-Party Extension:

If you’re not comfortable with coding, you can use a third-party extension to implement the magnifier widget in your Magento 2 store. There are many extensions available in the Magento Marketplace that offer different types of magnifier widgets with various features and customization options. You can choose an extension that best fits your needs and install it in your store.

Congratulations, you have successfully implemented a magnifier widget in Magento 2!

Conclusion

In summary, adding a magnifier widget to your online store can improve the user experience by enabling customers to zoom in on product images. To implement the widget in Magento 2, you need to create a new theme, or module, or use a template file or programmatic approach. These steps can optimize your Magento 2 store for a more satisfying shopping experience for customers. The suitability of either approach depends on specific needs, and it’s critical to consider the advantages and disadvantages before choosing. Create the widget programmatically in Magento 2 that grants more control over its behavior, while using a template file may be more suitable for simpler use cases. Ultimately, the best approach depends on your store’s requirements and goals.

nodes.title: How to Optimize Your Magento 2 for Voice Search
nodes.excerpt: A recent study conducted by OC&C Strategy Consultants reveals that the trend of voice-assisted shopping is on the rise and is expected to contribute an extra $40 billion in revenue in the year 2022. This growth can be attributed to the increasing number of people using their mobile devices for shopping, as well as the … Read more
nodes.content:
A recent study conducted by OC&C Strategy Consultants reveals that the trend of voice-assisted shopping is on the rise and is expected to contribute an extra $40 billion in revenue in the year 2022. This growth can be attributed to the increasing number of people using their mobile devices for shopping, as well as the rising sales of smart speakers.

With the trend of on-the-go shopping and the growing popularity of voice search, it’s crucial to optimize your online store for mobile search, including incorporating the main keyword How to add Google Analytics code to Magento 2 in the question you’re looking to answer

To make the most of your mobile commerce (M2), it is essential to optimize it for mobile search. This can be achieved by focusing on voice search optimization. To achieve this, it is crucial to understand the language and keywords that your customers use and create content that is short, simple, and optimized for voice search. In this article, we will delve into the topic of How to Optimize Your Magento 2 for Voice Search and provide practical tips on how to achieve this.

A Guide to Optimize Your Magento 2 for Voice Search

Why consider adding voice search to your Magento 2?

Voice Search on the Rise: Why 41% of Adults and 55% of Teens in the US are Opting for this Convenient Technology

What is driving the popularity of voice search?

Accessibility

Voice search appeals to certain groups of people who find it difficult or impossible to type their search queries, including:

  •  People with physical disabilities
  •  People with cognitive or learning disabilities
  •  People who are temporarily unable to use a keyboard or mouse, such as those with a broken arm.

Speed

Voice search allows users to quickly enter information and issue commands to their devices, making it faster than manual input.

Convenience

Voice search is available to users on the go, no matter where they are or what they are doing.

Smart speakers also employ AI that analyses the shopping experience of your visitors and provides personalized results based on their preferences. For example, if your Magento 2 store sells pet products and the AI recognizes that a customer regularly buys dog food, it may remind them to add it to their shopping cart. The advancement of technology is intensifying competition among vendors.

How does voice search influence the Magento 2 shopping process?

The impact of voice search on e-commerce cannot be overlooked, with a significant number of smart speaker owners, approximately 36%, now utilizing voice search for online shopping activities like product search, comparison, and checkout. This percentage is expected to increase to 55% within the next two years.

The growing popularity of voice search is attributable to its convenience and speed. Voice search can process up to 100 words per minute, which is three times faster than typing speed. As a result, many Magento 2 merchants are now implementing voice search functionality on their websites to meet customer demands and retain both current and potential customers.

To optimize your Magento 2 website for voice search, it is essential to understand the changing customer behavior and incorporate natural language keywords and concise content that is optimized for voice search. This is in line with the guidelines provided in How to Optimize Your Magento 2 for Voice Search. By doing so, your online store can stay competitive and meet the evolving needs of your customers.

To achieve this, it is crucial to optimize the Magento 2 website for voice search by understanding customer language, using natural language keywords, and creating concise and relevant content. By focusing on Magento 2 Website Optimization for Voice Search, online stores can stay ahead of the curve and deliver an exceptional shopping experience to their customers.

How does voice search affect Magento 2 SEO? How to optimize your website to voice search?

When it comes to voice search, the length and format of keywords can vary from those used in text searches. As a result, different websites may appear at the top of search engine results pages (SERPs).

To ensure your e-commerce site stays relevant, here are 5 tips to help you Optimize Magento 2 Store for Voice Search:

Tip 1: Mobile Optimization

As the global share of mobile sales in e-commerce is expected to reach 70% of total sales by 2020, according to Statista, and with 27% of users worldwide using voice search on mobile devices, mobile optimization is crucial to maintaining a top ranking in voice search results.

Here are some steps to optimize your Magento 2 store for mobile:

1. Develop a mobile version of your store

2. Test and improve the mobile loading speed

3. Ensure optimal user experience through design testing

4. Synchronize desktop and mobile responses, such as configuring consistent redirects

5. Include all mobile pages in your sitemap and verify they are visible to Googlebot

6. Maintain consistency between desktop and mobile content and metadata

7. Re-test mobile speed to ensure changes haven’t negatively impacted it.

Additionally, consider utilizing PWA technology or the AMP extension to create lightweight mobile pages for your website. Pages created using AMP are 85% faster than non-AMP pages, and the AMP extension allows for the creation of AMP versions for any CMS page.

Tip 2: Achieve Google’s Zero Results Blocks

Ranking at the top of the search results, or a “zero result,” means that Google considers your answer to be the best and will read it out loud to voice searchers. This block was created to allow users to see the answer without having to click on a website link, conserving Google’s resources for indexing millions of pages.

Here are a few suggestions on how to achieve zero results:

  •  Utilize informational keywords and queries that already have zero results;
  •  Incorporate the main keyword in the question you’re looking to answer;
  •  Provide a concise and relevant answer to that question, using lists and bullet points.

Tip 3: Prioritize a Semantic Approach Over Keyword Stuffing

With the advent of Google’s Hummingbird algorithm, context, and long-tail keywords have become increasingly important for improving search rankings. This algorithm prioritizes natural language, with the goal of making online interactions more human-like. Most SEO experts agree that adhering strictly to keyword usage, especially in regard to voice search, is outdated and ineffective. Instead, you should focus on your visitors’ needs and the task that your content should solve.

When it comes to voice search queries, they tend to be longer than text-based ones and often include question words like “how,” “why,” and “where.” This makes prioritizing a semantic strategy even more crucial.

Tip 4. Focus on Speed Optimization

Your website’s load time can play a significant role in retaining or losing visitors. Research shows that over 50% of customers will abandon a website if it takes more than 3 seconds to load. When it comes to voice search, users expect even faster results. To optimize your website’s speed, follow these steps:

1. Test your website using Google PageSpeed Insight to assess the current speed;

2. Analyze the results and use the recommendations to make necessary improvements;

3. Re-test your website to ensure that the changes have had a positive impact.

Some common speed optimization tips include resizing images, deferring offscreen images, and minifying CSS and JS files. You can use a tool like Google Page Speed Optimizer to help with these tasks. This plugin optimizes JS, CSS, and HTML code resizes pictures for mobile devices without sacrificing quality, and offers lazy loading for JS files.

For Magento 2 specifically, consider following the beginner’s guide for improving load speed, implementing the 4 main javascript optimization techniques, and leveraging browser caching.

Tip 5. Re-evaluate your Customer Journey Map (CJM) with voice search in mind

To maximize conversions, it’s important to understand the behavior of voice searchers and how it differs from text searches. By analyzing the voice purchase funnel, you can uncover the steps customers take before making a purchase and identify where they may be dropping off. Without a re-evaluated CJM, it will be difficult to understand the best ways to convert these customers.

As a helpful resource, consider exploring the infographic on 30 must-have features for Magento 2 to enhance your e-commerce site’s functionality and increase conversions.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the impact of voice search on e-commerce can be summarized by the following key points:

  • Over 110 million people use voice search on a daily basis, and 27% of global mobile users use it as well.
  • Mobile sales account for 65-70% of e-commerce traffic, making it essential for online stores to optimize for voice search.
  • SEO strategy for voice search differs from text-based searches, as voice searches often include longer keyword phrases and questions.
  • Google is using mobile-first indexing, the Google Hummingbird algorithm, and zero blocks to improve the user experience.
  • To optimize your Magento 2 store for voice search, it is crucial to understand the impact of voice search on customer behavior and develop a voice search purchase funnel that incorporates natural language keywords and short, concise content.

By following the guidelines outlined in How to Optimize Your Magento 2 for Voice Search, online stores can stay ahead of the curve and meet the changing demands of their customers.

nodes.title: How to Choose Best hosting for Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is an e-commerce platform equipped with diverse features that allow businesses to build and manage their online stores. Nonetheless, its optimal functionality necessitates a hosting environment with elevated resources and performance. A well-tuned hosting environment is indispensable to ensure that your Magento 2 store operates seamlessly and provides a secure, rapid, and dependable … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is an e-commerce platform equipped with diverse features that allow businesses to build and manage their online stores. Nonetheless, its optimal functionality necessitates a hosting environment with elevated resources and performance.

A well-tuned hosting environment is indispensable to ensure that your Magento 2 store operates seamlessly and provides a secure, rapid, and dependable user experience for your clientele. The selection of the appropriate hosting provider that sustains the Magento 2 setup is a vital measure in this undertaking. A trustworthy hosting provider should furnish you with the required infrastructure to efficiently operate your store and furnish assistance for any technical setbacks during the setup process.

This blog will cover the factors for how to choose the best hosting for Magento 2.

Factors to Choose the Best Hosting Provider in Magento 2

1. Performance and Speed

When it comes to selecting a hosting provider for Magento 2, there are several factors to consider. Firstly, performance and speed are critical because Magento 2 demands substantial resources, and a sluggish website can lead to a decrease in sales. A hosting provider that has optimized servers for Magento 2, fast processors, SSD storage, and enough RAM is highly recommended.

2. Scalability

Scalability is another important factor since you want your hosting provider to manage the growth of your business. As Magento 2 stores can grow rapidly, you need a hosting provider that can handle the increased traffic and server load. VPS or cloud hosting are scalable solutions that should be offered.

3. Security

Security is also crucial because your online store contains sensitive data like customer information and payment details. Your hosting provider should provide top-of-the-line security features such as SSL certificates, daily backups, and DDoS protection.

4. Support

When it comes to running an online business, having reliable and responsive support from your hosting provider is key. Your hosting provider should have a support team that’s available around the clock, and reachable through various channels such as email, phone, and live chat.

5. Cost

While cost is certainly an important factor to consider, you mustn’t compromise on performance, speed, or security by choosing the cheapest option available. Instead, select a hosting provider that offers good value for your money, and ensures that your online store runs smoothly without any hiccups. It’s also important to note that not all hosting providers support Magento 2, so make sure to choose one that specifically caters to this platform.

6. Magento 2 Compatibility

When it comes to selecting a hosting provider for Magento 2, it’s important to choose a provider that specifically supports the platform, as not all hosting providers are compatible. Checking for system requirements, including the required PHP version and extensions, is crucial to ensure that your provider meets the necessary criteria for effective Magento 2 hosting.

7. Reputation and Reviews

Last but not least, consider the reputation of your hosting provider. Research thoroughly and read reviews from other Magento 2 store owners to gauge their experiences. Opt for a hosting provider with a good reputation that’s known for its reliability and excellent service.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the selection of the appropriate hosting provider is critical to the triumph of your Magento 2 ecommerce store. It is essential to consider the above-mentioned factors, conduct extensive research, and opt for a hosting provider that meets your requirements and offers exceptional performance, scalability, security, support, and value for your investment.

nodes.title: How To Disable Magento 2 Profiler
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that empowers online businesses to create and manage their e-commerce websites. One of its notable features is the profiler, which is a tool that assists developers in optimizing the performance of their Magento 2 installation. Nevertheless, the profiler can potentially hinder a website’s performance, and therefore, disabling it … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that empowers online businesses to create and manage their e-commerce websites. One of its notable features is the profiler, which is a tool that assists developers in optimizing the performance of their Magento 2 installation. Nevertheless, the profiler can potentially hinder a website’s performance, and therefore, disabling it may become essential. This article aims to guide you on how to disable Magento 2 profiler.

What is  Profiler in Magento 2

– The profiler in Magento 2 is a built-in feature that provides developers with valuable insights into their website’s performance. It enables developers to pinpoint areas where website speed and user experience may be affected, such as bottlenecks or slow-loading areas.

– The profiler generates detailed information on page load times, including the time taken to execute each process that makes up the page. Additionally, the profiler can also track the time it takes for media, such as images, to load as the user scrolls down the page by enabling lazy loading in Magento 2.

– However, the profiler can also have a negative impact on website performance by adding extra processing time and generating large log files that consume server resources. Disabling the profiler can help to speed up website performance and reduce the use of server resources, which is especially beneficial for high-traffic websites or those hosted on shared servers with limited resources.

– However, it’s important to note that disabling the profiler can also make it more challenging to troubleshoot and optimize the website in the future, as it removes a vital diagnostic tool for developers. Therefore, website owners and developers should carefully consider the tradeoffs of disabling the profiler before making any changes. It’s recommended to consult with a Magento 2 expert or perform some performance testing before making any decisions.

Steps to Disable Magento 2 Profiler

Step 1: Disable the profiler in the Magento 2 admin panel

The first step to disabling the Magento 2 profiler is to do so in the admin panel. You can do this by navigating to Stores > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Debug and setting “Enabled Template Path Hints for Storefront” and “Enabled Template Path Hints for Admin” to “No”.

Step 2: Disable the profiler in the Magento 2 configuration file

The second step to disabling the Magento 2 profiler is to do so in the configuration file. You can do this by opening the app/etc/env.php file in a text editor and adding the following code to the file:

php

'debug' =>Â 

Â Â array (

Â Â Â Â 'profiler' =>Â 

Â Â Â Â array (

Â Â Â Â Â Â 'enabled' => false,

Â Â Â Â ),

Â Â ),

This code disables the profiler by setting the “enabled” value to false.

Step 3: Disable the profiler in the Magento 2 index.php file

The third step to disabling the Magento 2 profiler is to do so in the index.php file. You can do this by opening the index.php file in a text editor and adding the following code to the file:

php

if ($_SERVER['MAGE_PROFILER']) {

Â Â Â Â \Magento\Framework\Profiler::disable();

}

This code disables the profiler by checking the MAGE_PROFILER environment variable and disabling the profiler if it is set.

Step 4: Clear the cache

After making these changes, it is important to clear the Magento 2 cache to ensure that the changes take effect. You can do this by running the following command from your Magento 2 root directory:

python

php bin/magento cache:clean

Conclusion

Disabling the Magento 2 profiler can greatly enhance the performance of your e-commerce website. By following the steps provided, disabling the profiler can be done quickly and easily. It is essential to keep in mind, however, that while this can lead to better performance, it may also impede future debugging and optimization. Therefore, careful consideration should be given to the effects of disabling the profiler before taking action.

nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a highly customizable e-commerce platform that enables you to create an online store that aligns with your unique business requirements. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a highly customizable e-commerce platform that enables you to create an online store that aligns with your unique business requirements. One of the many powerful features of Magento 2 is the ability of Configuring Magento 2 customer accounts with customer groups. Customer groups allow you to segment your customers based on various criteria, such as purchase history, location, or website behavior, enabling you to offer personalized experiences to each group, including tailored product recommendations, discounts, or promotions.

Programmatically creating customer groups in Magento 2 is a crucial feature for developers and store owners who want to streamline the process of creating customer groups. This can save time and reduce the likelihood of errors that can occur when creating customer groups manually through the admin panel. By creating customer groups programmatically, you can ensure that all groups are created consistently, with the same settings and attributes, which can help you maintain a more organized and efficient customer management system.

In this tutorial, we’ll take you through the steps of creating customer groups programmatically in Magento 2, using a custom module and the Group Factory class. Whether you’re a developer aiming to integrate this feature into your online store or a store owner seeking to enhance your customer management system, this tutorial has got you covered. You’ll find all the necessary steps to get started with creating customer groups programmatically in Magento 2.

Steps to Create Customer Groups Programmatically in Magento 2

Step 1: Create a Module

The first step is to create a module to contain our custom code. To do this, create a new directory in the app/code directory with the name of your module. For example, if you want to name your module “Custom”, you would create the directory app/code/Custom.

Inside this directory, create a registration.php file with the following contents:

php

<?php

\Magento\Framework\Component\ComponentRegistrar::register(

Â Â Â Â \Magento\Framework\Component\ComponentRegistrar::MODULE,

Â Â Â Â 'Custom_CustomerGroup',

Â Â Â Â __DIR__

);

This registers your module with Magento.

Next, create a module.xml file with the following contents:

xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:framework:Module/etc/module.xsd">

Â Â Â Â <module name="Custom_CustomerGroup" setup_version="1.0.0" />

</config>

This defines the name and version of your module.

Step 2: Create a Customer Group

Now that we have our module set up, we can create a customer group programmatically. To do this, create a new file in the Custom/CustomerGroup directory called InstallData.php with the following contents:

php

<?php

namespace Custom\CustomerGroup\Setup;

use Magento\Customer\Model\GroupFactory;

use Magento\Framework\Setup\InstallDataInterface;

use Magento\Framework\Setup\ModuleContextInterface;

use Magento\Framework\Setup\ModuleDataSetupInterface;

class InstallData implements InstallDataInterface

{

Â Â Â Â private $groupFactory;

Â Â Â Â public function __construct(GroupFactory $groupFactory)

Â Â Â Â {

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $this->groupFactory = $groupFactory;

Â Â Â Â }

Â Â Â Â public function install(ModuleDataSetupInterface $setup, ModuleContextInterface $context)

Â Â Â Â {

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $setup->startSetup();

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â // Create customer group

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $groupName = 'My Group';

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $groupCode = 'my_group';

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $taxClassId = 3;

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $this->groupFactory->create()

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ->setCode($groupCode)

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ->setTaxClassId($taxClassId)

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ->setCustomerGroupCode($groupName)

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ->save();

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â $setup->endSetup();

Â Â Â Â }

}

This file defines a class that implements the Install Data Interface interface. This interface provides a method called install(), which is called during the installation of the module. In the install() method, we create a new customer group using the Group Factory class. We set the name, code, and tax class ID for the group, and then save it using the save() method.

In this example, we have set the name of the group to “My Group”, the code to “my_group”, and the tax class ID to 3. You can change these values to suit your needs.

Step 3: Run the Setup Script

To run the setup script and create the customer group, we need to run the following command in the root directory of your Magento 2 installation:

bash

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

This will run the setup script for all installed modules, including our custom module. Once the script has completed, the new customer group should be available in the Magento 2 admin panel.

Conclusion

In summary, this tutorial demonstrated how to create a customer group programmatically in Magento 2. By creating customer groups, you can segment your customer base and offer personalized experiences to each group. The tutorial covered creating a custom module, implementing the Install Data Interface interface, and creating a customer group using the Group Factory class. After running the setup script, the new customer group will be available in the Magento 2 admin panel.

Creating customer groups in Magento 2 programmatically is a robust feature that allows you to automate the creation of customer groups and tailor your marketing strategies to specific groups. By creating custom customer groups, you can offer exclusive promotions, discounts, and rewards to your most loyal customers. Furthermore, this method saves you time and minimizes the possibility of errors. Instead of manually creating customer groups through the admin panel, automating the process ensures that all customer groups are consistently created.

In conclusion, the ability to create customer groups programmatically in Magento 2 can be a valuable feature that can enhance the customer experience and drive sales on your online store. We sincerely hope that this tutorial has provided you with the necessary guidance to create customer groups using a custom module and the Group Factory class in Magento 2.

By default, the Cart Total is displayed above the Cart Items on the Checkout Page in Magento 2. However, if you want to change the position of … Read more
nodes.content:
In this article, we will guide you step-by-step on how to move the Cart Total section below the Cart Items section on the Checkout Page in Magento 2. By default, the Cart Total is displayed above the Cart Items on the Checkout Page in Magento 2. However, if you want to change the position of the Cart Total section and display it below the Cart Items section, follow the instructions provided in this guide. So, let’s get started on how to move cart total below cart items in checkout page in Magento 2.

How to Move Cart Total Below Cart Items in Checkout Page in Magento 2: A Step-by-Step Guide

Are you looking to change the default configuration of the Magento 2 checkout page and move the cart total below the cart items? This can easily be achieved by following a few simple steps. In this guide, we will provide you with a comprehensive tutorial on how to move the cart total below the cart items in the checkout page in Magento 2. By the end of this tutorial, you will have the knowledge and skills to make this change to your Magento 2 checkout page. So, let’s get started!

Step 1: Create an Override File

In order to move the cart total, you need to override the checkout_index_index.xml file in your module or theme, depending on your specific requirements. If you want to create the file for your theme, you need to create it in the following path:

app/design/frontend/Vendor/theme/Magento_Checkout/layout/checkout_index_index.xml

If you want to create the file for your module, you need to create it in the following path:

app/code/Vendor/Module/view/frontend/layout/checkout_index_index.xml

nodes.content:
In Magento 2, it may be necessary to create new Admin accounts for various members of your organization. This will give them access to the backend of your store, allowing them to perform their assigned tasks. User Roles can also be created to specify different levels of access and permissions for each user. This tutorial will walk you through the process of creating a User Role in Magento 2, giving you complete control over what content each user can view and edit. By following these steps, you’ll be able to learn how to create user role in Magento 2 quickly and easily.

How to Create User Role in Magento 2: A Step-by-Step Guide to Managing User Permissions

Magento 2 offers two convenient methods for creating a new Admin User:

1. Through the Magento Admin Interface

Creating a new Magento 2 Admin user through the backend is a simple process. Follow these steps:

1.Go to Admin -> System -> Permissions -> All Users -> Add New User.

2. Fill in the account information for the new user, making sure that the email address is unique. Confirm your current user’s identity by entering Your Password.

3. In the Interface Locale section, select the language you want the backend to be displayed in for the new user (if your store has multiple languages).

4. Optionally, set the Expiration Date for the account by selecting a date in the calendar next to the Expiration Date.

5. Navigate to the User Role section using the menu on the left-hand side of the page.

6. Select the role you want the new user to have.

7. Click Save User. You will see a success notification and the new user will appear in the User List.

And that’s it! You have successfully created a new Magento 2 Admin user.

2. Using the Command Line Interface

Creating a new Admin User through the Command Line Interface in Magento 2 involves the following steps:

1. Connect to your server via SSH and navigate to the root of your Magento 2 project.

2. Enter the command: php bin/magento admin:user: create

3. Fill in the configuration variables when prompted:

  • Admin user
  • Admin password
  • Admin email
  • Admin first name
  • Admin last name

4. After completing the details, you will receive a success message.

With these steps, you have successfully created a new Admin through the Command Line Interface in Magento 2.

Creating User Roles in Magento 2

Steps to Create User Role in Magento 2:

1.Go to Admin Panel > System > Permissions > User Roles. You will see a list of the current user roles which can be edited.

2. Click the Add New Role button to create a new user role.

3. Fill in the Role Information:

  •  In the Role Name field, set a name for the user role.
  •  In the Your Password field, confirm your identity by entering your current password. This is for security purposes and allows you to add or edit the role.

4. Go to the Role Resources tab and select the resources the admin will have access to:

  •  If you want the user to have access to all pages and capabilities of the admin panel, choose ‘All’ in the Resource Access field.
  •  To provide access to specific interfaces, choose ‘Custom’ in the Resource Access field and select the desired interfaces.

5. After completing the steps, remember to click the Save Role button.

Conclusion

In conclusion, How to Configure Magento 2 Customer Accounts is an essential aspect of managing a successful e-commerce store. nodes.content:
If you are running an eCommerce store on Magento 2, you need to be familiar with its shipping methods. Shipping methods refer to the cost and mode of delivery for a product to the customer. Offering multiple shipping methods can enhance the customer experience and even influence their purchasing decisions. Hence, it is essential to understand the basic shipping configurations in Magento 2 and the default shipping methods available.

In this article, we will discuss how to configure shipping methods in Magento 2. We will cover the different types of shipping methods categorized based on delivery type, and provide an overview of the default shipping methods available in Magento 2. This guide will help you to understand and manage the Magento 2 shipping methods effectively to improve your eCommerce store’s shipping options.

How to Configure Shipping Methods in Magento 2: A Step-by-Step Guide to Optimizing Your Store’s Delivery Options

How to Configure Magento 2 Shipping Settings?

In order to effectively configure the default shipping methods available in Magento 2, it’s necessary to first set up the default shipping settings. This can be done by navigating to Stores > Configuration > Sales > Shipping Settings.

Here, you’ll need to configure the Origin and Shipping Policy Parameters, which will allow Magento to calculate taxes and shipping costs based on the shipping origin.

The information you’ll need to provide includes:

  • Country
  • Region/State
  • ZIP/Postal Code
  • City
  • Street Address/Street Address Line 2

Additionally, you can choose to Apply a custom Shipping Policy and provide the text for it, which will be displayed during checkout.

How to Configure Default Magento 2 Shipping Methods?

Once you finish with the basic shipping settings, you’re good to go and configure shipping methods. They are managed in Stores > Configuration > Sales > Shipping Methods.

Flat Rate Shipping Method

Flat Rate is the standard shipping method in Magento 2, which can be applied either per single item or per order, regardless of the product attributes such as size or weight.

There are some common options for every shipping method, such as Title, Enable/Disable, and Method Name, but let’s focus on the unique ones.

1. In the Type field, you can define how the shipping fee is added to the subtotal. There are three options: None, Per Item, and Per Order.

  •  None means no charge is applied, making a Flat Rate equivalent to Free transporting.
  •  Per Order means the charge is applied to the entire order, not each item separately.
  •  Per Item means the Flat Rate shipping fee is set for each item and multiplied by the number of items in the cart.

2. Set the Price you would like to charge for the Flat Rate Shipping.

3. Determine the method for Calculating the Handling Fee.

4. Set the amount of the Handling Fee based on the method you selected for handling fee calculation. For example, if you choose to calculate the handling fee from the order subtotal as a percentage, you would enter 0.08 for 8%.

5. Fill in the Displayed Error Message field with the text customers will see when the Flat Rate Shipping is unavailable.

6. In the Ship to Applicable Countries select box, choose whether you want to ship to all allowed countries or select specific countries.

7. Decide if you want to Show Method if Not Applicable, which determines if the Flat Rate shipping method will be displayed during checkout even if it can’t be applied to the order.

8. Set the Sort Order to determine the place of the Flat Rate method in the list of shipping methods.

Free Shipping Method

Free shipping is one of the most popular and customer-attracting shipping types used in Magento 2. It provides merchants with the ability to offer customers free shipping based on a minimum order amount and to set up cart price rules if the conditions are met.

The configuration for free transporting is similar to the previous method, however, you can delve deeper into the free shipping configuration to learn how to effectively promote it.

Table Rates Shipping Method

The Table Rates shipping method in Magento 2 calculates shipping fees based on various conditions, such as weight versus destination, price versus destination, and the number of items versus the destination.

This means that the cost of Table Rates shipping can vary based on the customer’s address and the number of items they order, or the weight of the items.

While Table Rates are similar to the Flat Rate shipping method, it has some distinct features, such as:

1. Select the condition rates will be calculated under.

2. Determine if virtual products should be included in price calculation with the “Include Virtual Products in Price Calculation” option. Note: virtual products do not have a weight, so they will not affect the results of the weight versus destination condition calculation.

To complete the default Table Rates configuration, you will need to prepare or update the table rate files.

3. In the Stores > Configuration section, switch to the desired store view or website to apply this shipping setting. Two new options will appear.

4. Export the CSV file, make any necessary updates, and then import it.

5. Visit the storefront and make several orders with different destinations to see how the Table Rates shipping fees are calculated.

Dimensional Weight Shipment in Magento 2

The Magento 2 Dimensional Shipping method calculates shipping rates based on the dimensions (volume, weight) or amount of space occupied by the package.

Here are the steps to configure the Dimensional Shipping method:

1. Enable DHL for checkout to display it during the checkout process.

2. Give the shipping method a Title and enter the Access ID, Password, and Account Number.

3. Set the Content-Type (Non-Domestic).

4. Manage the Handling Fee by specifying the type of calculation, the amount applied, and the handling fee amount.

5. Choose to divide the order weight into smaller units to accurately calculate the shipping charge.

6. Set the weight measurement units and size for the calculations.

7. Select the supported Documents Allowed Methods and Non Documents Allowed Methods.

8. Specify the ready time in the Ready Time field, indicating when the package will be ready for pickup after the order is placed.

9. Fill in the Displayed Error Message field with the text customers will see when DHL is unavailable.

10. Choose the preferred shipping method for free shipping offers using the Free Method setting.

11. Enable the Free Shipping Threshold to allow for free DHL shipping for orders that meet the minimum amount.

12. Configure the applicable countries for shipping, visibility, and sort order in the same manner as the other shipping methods.

13. Enable Debug to create a log file with error information.

14. Enable the Sandbox Mode to run DHL transactions in a test environment.

After you configure the shipping methods, don’t forget to Save Config.

And this is how the shipping methods will be displayed on the storefront:

To provide a better customer experience you have to take into account a lot of things in your store, and shipping methods are not an exception.

If you want to provide your customers with the best shopping experience, it’s essential to offer them different shipping options to choose from. As shipping is a crucial aspect of the purchase process, it’s essential to be aware of all the available options for both you and your customers. In this article, we will discuss how to configure shipping methods in Magento 2, so you can offer your customers a seamless and efficient delivery experience.

Conclusion

In conclusion, it is crucial to have a clear understanding of how a newly placed order is managed in the Magento 2 store . If you’re running an eCommerce store on Magento 2, you need to know How to Configure Shipping Methods in Magento 2 to provide the best possible shipping experience to your customers. This involves offering a variety of shipping options and ensuring that the configuration is saved correctly to display the options on the storefront. Since shipping plays a significant role in the purchasing process, providing customers with different options enables them to choose what works best for them.

To set up shipping methods in Magento 2, it’s essential to understand all the available options for both the store owner and customers. Having this understanding is critical in providing a seamless and smooth ordering experience. After setting up the shipping methods, it’s crucial to save the config to display them correctly on the storefront.

This article provides a comprehensive guide on how to setup shipping methods in Magento 2. By following the steps outlined in this guide, store owners can provide customers with a variety of shipping options and improve the overall customer experience.

nodes.content:
In this guide, you’ll learn How to Configure Layered Navigation in Magento 2 Store to help customers quickly find the products they need. With Layered Navigation, customers can filter results based on attributes like price, category, and color, resulting in a smoother shopping experience.

We’ll cover everything from displaying the Layered Navigation menu on your category page to adding filterable attributes. Don’t risk losing customers due to poor navigation – use Magento 2’s powerful Layered Navigation feature to provide an optimal on-site experience for your customers.

Follow these steps to configure Layered Navigation in your Magento 2 store and make the most out of its capabilities.

How to Configure Layered Navigation in Magento 2 Store: A Complete Guide

The central objective of Magento 2’s Layered Navigation is to empower customers to swiftly find their desired product by filtering options based on attributes such as price, color, material, and others. This enhances the shopping experience by enabling customers to locate products that meet their specific needs.

Configure Price Filter in Layered Navigation

In Magento 2, you can customize your layered navigation settings, including price navigation, by navigating to Stores > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Layered Navigation in the general settings.

You will find two fields that must be set in the layered navigation configuration:

1. Display Product Count – determines if the number of products matching product attributes, price, or category will be displayed next to the layered navigation options.

2. Price Navigation Step Calculation – defines the method used to calculate the price navigation step.

Magento 2 offers three methods for calculating the price navigation step:

1. Automatic (equalize price ranges) – determines the price navigation steps automatically based on the price range of products in a group.

2. Automatic (equalize product count) – calculates the price navigation steps automatically based on the number of products in a group. This option includes additional fields, such as:

  •  Display Price Interval as One Price – to be enabled when all prices in a specific interval are equal.
  • Interval Division Limit – the number of products that will not be divided into subintervals.

3. Manual – allows customers to set prices for layered navigation manually. In this case, you can configure the following options:

  •  Default Price Navigation Step – determines the number of products included in each step.
  •  Maximum Number of Price Intervals – defines the maximum number of price intervals available in Magento 2 layered navigation.

Configure Layered Navigation with Filterable Attributes

Magento 2’s Layered Navigation does not include product attributes by default. To allow customers to filter products by attributes, you must manually configure it.

It is important to note that not all product attributes can be added to layered navigation. Only attributes with dropdown, multiple select, or price input types are eligible for inclusion.

If there is no suitable attribute to add to layered navigation, you can create a new attribute and assign it to the attribute set.

To add product attributes to Magento 2’s Layered Navigation, follow these steps:

1. Go to Stores > Attributes > Products and select the attribute you want to add to layered navigation.

Note: You will notice that the ‘Use in Layered Navigation’ section has already been added to the product attribute options.

2. Navigate to the Storefront Properties section of the Attribute Information.

3. In the ‘Use in Layered Navigation’ dropdown, select either ‘Filterable (with results)’ to display the number of products in the category associated with this attribute, or ‘Filterable (no results)’ if you don’t want to display the product count.

4. To display this attribute on the search results pages, select ‘Yes’ in the ‘Use in Search Results Layered Navigation’ option.

5. Remember to click ‘Save Attribute’ once you’ve made the necessary changes.

How to display Layered Navigation on Magento 2 Category Page?

To display the layered navigation menu on a Magento 2 category page:

1. Go to Calatog > Categories.

2. Choose the desired category and enable the ‘Anchor’ option in its Display Settings.

The Layered Navigation menu in Magento 2 offers a convenient way for customers to search for products by filtering available options. This enhances the shopping experience and improves engagement in your store. You can display the layered navigation on any category page by enabling the Anchor option in the Display Settings. Additionally, you can adjust the placement of the menu by configuring the category design in the Design section.

As an e-commerce store owner, you want to create a shopping environment that encourages customers to return. One way to achieve this is by configuring Layered Navigation in your Magento 2 store. By adding multiple attributes to the Layered Navigation, customers can quickly find products of interest by using different parameters. This simplifies the navigation process through the product catalog and creates a shopping environment that is user-friendly and efficient.

But personalizing the customer experience goes beyond just providing Layered Navigation. You can also display recently viewed products or allow customers to compare products, increasing the chances of a purchase. The best part is that you don’t need an extension to achieve this.

By following these simple tips on how to configure Layered Navigation in Magento 2 Store, you can create an exceptional shopping experience for your customers. With Layered Navigation, you can help customers find what they’re looking for quickly and efficiently. By personalizing the experience through recently viewed products and product comparisons, you can increase customer engagement and drive sales. So, take the time to configure Layered Navigation and other features in your Magento 2 store to create a shopping environment that puts the customer first.

Conclusion

In the world of e-commerce, providing an exceptional shopping experience for customers is paramount. One way to achieve this is by configuring Layered Navigation in your Magento 2 store. By enabling customers to filter products based on attributes such as price, color, and material, Layered Navigation streamlines the navigation process and helps customers find what they’re looking for quickly.

So, How to setup Layered Navigation in Magento 2 Store? First, enable Layered Navigation on multiple categories to ensure that customers can filter their searches regardless of the category they’re browsing. Next, add product attributes to give customers more filtering options. Additionally, customizing the design of the Layered Navigation menu to fit your store’s aesthetic can make it more inviting and user-friendly.

But don’t stop there! There are other ways to personalize the customer experience beyond Layered Navigation. For example, displaying recently viewed products can help customers quickly revisit items they were interested in. Allowing product comparisons can also give customers the information they need to make informed purchasing decisions.

By implementing these strategies, you’ll not only improve customer engagement but also increase the chances of making sales. So, take the time to configure Layered Navigation and other features in your Magento 2 store to create a shopping environment that puts the customer first. With these tips on how to configure Layered Navigation in Magento 2 store, you can create an exceptional shopping experience for your customers.

nodes.excerpt: As an online store owner using Magento 2, managing your products effectively is crucial to delivering an optimal shopping experience for your customers. However, there may be situations where you need to retrieve a product collection filtered by category … Read more
nodes.content:
As an online store owner using Magento 2, managing your products effectively is crucial to delivering an optimal shopping experience for your customers. Organizing your products into different categories is a fundamental aspect of efficiently managing your product offerings.

However, there may be situations where you need to retrieve a product collection filtered by category ID to create customized product lists or apply specific filters. In this article, we will provide you with a detailed, step-by-step guide on how to get product collection by category ID in Magento 2.

By following these instructions, you will be able to manage your products more efficiently, resulting in an organized and user-friendly online store for your customers to navigate.

Why do we need to get a collection of products by category ID?

On some occasions, we need to access all the products belonging to a specific category, such as displaying products on the frontend and applying filters. In such cases, we can obtain a product collection filtered by category ID.

How to Get Product Collection by Category ID in Magento 2

There are two methods to get a product collection filtered by category ID in Magento 2. Let’s have a look at both methods in detail.

Method 1: Using the Object Manager

The Object Manager is an integral part of Magento 2’s architecture and is used to manage the instantiation of objects in the system. To get the product collection filtered by category ID using the Object Manager, follow the below steps.

1. First, create an object of the Object Manager in your block file as follows:

php

protected $_objectManager;

public function __construct(

    \Magento\Framework\ObjectManagerInterface $objectManager,

    ...

) {

    $this->_objectManager = $objectManager;

    ...

}

1.Then, create a method that returns the product collection filtered by category ID as follows:

php

public function getProductCollection($categoryId)

{

    $category = $this->_objectManager->create(\Magento\Catalog\Model\Category::class)->load($categoryId);

    $collection = $this->_objectManager->create(\Magento\Catalog\Model\ResourceModel\Product\Collection::class);

    $collection->addAttributeToSelect('*');

    $collection->addCategoryFilter($category);

    return $collection;

}

In this method, first, we load the category using the load method of the category model and then create a product collection using the create method of the Object Manager. Next, we add all the attributes to select using the addAttributeToSelect method, and then filter the collection by category ID using the addCategoryFilter method. Finally, the method returns the filtered product collection.

Method 2: Using the Product Repository

The Product Repository is a service layer in Magento 2 that provides an interface to manage product data. To get the product collection filtered by category ID using the Product Repository, follow the below steps.

1. First, inject the ProductRepository interface in your block file as follows:

php

protected $productRepository;

public function __construct(

    ...

    \Magento\Catalog\Api\ProductRepositoryInterface $productRepository,

    ...

) {

    ...

    $this->productRepository = $productRepository;

    ...

}

1. Then, create a method that returns the product collection filtered by category ID as follows:

php

public function getProductCollection($categoryId)

{

    $collection = $this->productRepository->getList(

        \Magento\Framework\Api\SearchCriteriaBuilder::create()

            ->addFilter('category_id', $categoryId, 'eq')

->create()

);

return $collection->getItems();

}

sql

In this method, we first create a search criteria using the `SearchCriteriaBuilder` class. Then, we add a filter for category ID using the `addFilter` method and set the condition to ‘eq’ (equal). Finally, we call the `getList` method of the `ProductRepository` interface to get the filtered product collection and return the result using the `getItems` method.

Conclusion

This blog post highlights two methods to achieve this task: one employing the Object Manager and the other utilizing the Product Repository. Both methods are simple and can be implemented as per specific requirements. I trust that this blog post has helped comprehend the process of getting a product collection filtered by category ID in Magento 2.
